useMaq.tipHTML: Multi-Archive Querying (MAQ) allows the user to search for data hosted by other astronomical data centers in addition to data hosted by the CADC. The ‘Additional Constraints’ region of this page will reload with the additional MAQ content and existing selections will be reset.

Observation.observationID.tipHTML:
An identifier string that uniquely identifies an observation within a collection. Syntax and examples are given below for the most commonly-accessed collections.
HST
Standard HST products have Observation IDs starting with a letter designating the instrument (I:WFC3, L:COS, J:ACS, U:WFPC2, O:STIS, N:NICMOS, Y:FOS, Z:HRS, W:WFPC, X:FOC).

Clickable examples:
  • U2IR0104T
  • ST_10921_01_WFPC2_F502N_WF
  • HST_10921_01_WFPC2*
HSTHLA
Hubble Legacy Archive products start with 'hst' and contain the proposal ID, instrument and filter.

Clickable examples:
  • hst_01070_0l_wfpc2_f555w_wf
  • hst_11595_15_wfc3_uvis_f390m
GEMINI
For raw data, this is the "Data Superset Name" (Science Program ID followed by observation and exposure number). For processed GMOS images '-mrg-add' is appended.

Clickable examples:
  • GN-2003A-C-2-52-003
  • GN-2003A-C-2-*
  • GS-2010A-Q-51-8-004-mrg-add
CFHT
For standard CFHT products this is the "exposure number" (exception is for Espadons polarization products which have 'p' appended). MegaPipe products begin with 'G', 'D', 'W', or 'N'. Terapix products begin with 'CFHTLS'.

Clickable examples:
  • 1220550
  • 1262607p
  • 12Am01.flat.i2.36.00
CFHTMEGAPIPE and CFHTWIRWOLF
MegaPipe products begin with 'G', 'D', 'W', or 'N' and contain the position and filter. WIRWOLF products begin with 'GW' and contain the position.

Clickable examples:
  • G011.160.199+57.876.Z
  • GW001.225.969+10.379
CFHTTERAPIX
Terapix products from the CFHT Legacy Survey begin with 'CFHTLS'.

Clickable examples:
  • CFHTLS_D-85_100028+021230
JCMT
For raw ACSIS and SCUBA-2 data and for reduced data products derived from single raw observations, the observation ID is the same as the observation identifier assigned by the JCMT. For composite products derived from raw data in multiple observations, the names are complex, but can include the UT date or project identifier.

Clickable examples:
  • 20070317-bea3df400bdc4f24ae2a57a4b07219d2
  • scuba2_00022_20120105T071833
  • scuba2*
  • acsis*20081109*
  • 20081109-*
  • M08BU04-*

Observation.proposal.pi.tipHTML:
Name of the Principal Investigator whose research has required one or more observations. This might not be relevant for Survey-based Observations. This field has an auto-complete function. Searches are case-insensitive, and wildcards are automatically appended to both ends of the input string. Be aware of the ordering of names if specifying first and last name.

Clickable examples:

  • Abraham Roberto
  • Roberto Abraham
  • Abraham

Observation.proposal.id.tipHTML:
Identifier of any proposals for which observations has been acquired and sourced within the archive. The syntax is highly dependent on the Collection. Searches are case-insensitive and wildcards are automatically appended to both ends of the input string.

Clickable examples:

  • 8303
  • 11BF05
  • GS-2008A-Q-69
  • M05BU59
  • GS-2008A

Observation.proposal.title.tipHTML:
The title of the scientific project for which a given observation has been acquired. Note that only some Collections include proposal titles. Searches are case-insensitive and wildcards are automatically appended to both ends of the input string.

Clickable examples:

  • The Shaping of Planetary Nebulae
  • SCUBA/BLAST

Observation.proposal.keywords.tipHTML:
Observation proposal specific keywords describing the type of observation or science goal. Multiple strings can be comma delimited. Note that only some Collections include proposal keywords. Searches are case-insensitive and wildcards are automatically appended to both ends of the input string.

Clickable examples:

  • Absorption lines
  • Active galaxies
  • Dynamics, Emission lines

Plane.dataRelease.tipHTML:
Check the box to only search for data that is publicly available for all users to download. Alternatively, search by the date at which the data become public. The date format can be either a single value time period, such as a year or day, a range specified by a beginning and end date separated by two dots, or before or after a certain date. Times can be included. Dates/times can be in JD, MJD, or ISO8601 format (date and time separated by space or the letter T). ISO8601 format must include at least the year (yyyy) and may include the complete date and time (yyyy-MM-dd hh:mm:ss.SSS) or a subset of the complete date and time.

Clickable examples:

  • 2013
  • 2013-02-28
  • 2013-03-01..2013-09-01
  • < 2013-03-01
  • < 2013-02-22T9:00:00

Observation.intent.tipHTML: The original observer's intent in producing an observation:<dl><dt>Science data:</dt><dd>intent to measure some astrophysical process</dd><dt>Calibration data:</dt><dd>intent to calibrate the detectors system (includes standard source observations)</dd></dl>

Plane.position.bounds.tipHTML:
Positions entered as RA & DEC in degrees or sexagesimal.

Target name resolution uses any resolvers in the drop-down menu or the original target designation of the observation if the "Deselect to query by string" checkbox is deselected.

Optional search radius (default unit is degrees) can be specified. If not specified a default radius of 1 arcminute is used. A coordinate system/epoch (ICRS [default], J2000, J2000.0, B1950, B1950.0, FK4, FK5, GAL) can be appended.

A range of RA and DEC or l and b may be specified using ".." syntax.

If the "Do Spatial Cutout" box is selected then the diameter of the image cutout is twice the specified radius.

Box labelled "Choose File" for multiple target file upload with one target per row.

Clickable examples:

  • M101
  • M101 0.5
  • M101 30arcmin
  • M101 30'
  • HD79158 0.05
  • cluster
  • 210.05 54.3
  • 210.05 54.3 0.5
  • 210.05 54.3 0.5 FK4
  • 210.05..210.15 54.2..54.4
  • 08:45:07.5 +54:18:00
  • 08:45:07.5 +54:18:00 0.5
  • 08 45 07.5 +54 18 00 0.5
  • 08h45m07.5s +54d18m00s 0.5
  • 0.0 0.0 GAL
  • 0.0..5.0 -5.0..0.0 GAL

To search for observations of solar system bodies follow the link to SSOIS.

Plane.position.sampleSize.tipHTML:
Select the range of pixel scale (aka spatial sample size per detector element), of the data. The default unit is arcseconds. Units of arcminutes and degrees are allowed.

Clickable examples:

  • 0.02..0.05
  • 10..20
  • 0.02..0.05arcmin
  • 0.02..0.05deg

Plane.position.DOWNLOADCUTOUT.tipHTML: Check this box to return image cutouts rather than full images. Cutouts will be centred on the location determined from the "Target" box. The size of the cutouts will be twice the radius specified in the "Target" box. If no radius is specified then a default of 1 arcmin is used. Cutouts for a list of targets from "Choose File" are not yet implemented.

Plane.time.bounds.samples.tipHTML:
Search for data whose time of observation overlaps a single time period (second, minute, hour, day, month, year), a range of times specified by a beginning and end time or before or after a certain date/time. Multiple values in a range must be separated by two dots. Times can be in JD, MJD, or ISO8601 format (date and time separated by space or the letter T). ISO8601 format must include at least the year (yyyy) and may include the complete date and time (yyyy-MM-dd hh:mm:ss.SSS) or a subset of the complete date and time.

Clickable examples:

  • 2010
  • 2010-09-22
  • > 2010-09-22
  • 2010-09-22 9:00:00
  • 2010-09-22T9:00:00
  • 2009-09-22 21:45..2009-09-23 05:30
  • 55453.7..55461.0
  • 2455454.2..2455461.5
  • Past 24 hours

Plane.time.exposure.tipHTML:
Length of time the instrument was collecting photons for the observation. For composite observations and data-cubes, integration time includes the integration of all open-shutter times of the input components (stacks) or layers (data-cubes). Default unit is seconds. Single values are discouraged due to rounding errors. Ranges can be specified by < or > symbols or by separating two values with two dots.

Clickable examples:

  • 0.5..1m
  • 2m..1h
  • 24.5..25.5
  • 25
  • < 25

Plane.time.bounds.width.tipHTML:
Often identical to the integration Time, but for composite observations where the Time Span is the difference between the minimum Start Time and the maximum Stop Time of each contributing observation. Default unit is days and other allowed units are second, minute, hour, year. Single values are discouraged due to rounding errors. Ranges can be specified by < or > symbols or by separating values with two dots.

Clickable examples:

  • 30s..1m
  • 1y..2y
  • 24.5..25.5
  • < 25

Plane.energy.bounds.samples.tipHTML:
Search using a single energy value or a range of energy values (default units are metres). Multiple values in a range should be separated by two dots. If the "Do Spectral Cutout" box is selected then a multiple range separated by two dots must be given to define the required cutout spectral range. Allowed wavelength, frequency, energy units are: [ Hz, kHz, MHz, GHz, cm, mm, um, nm, m, A, eV, keV, MeV, GeV ]

Clickable examples:

  • 0.21
  • 8E-7
  • 800nm
  • 800..1200nm
  • 300..400GHz
  • 800nm..5GeV
  • 32000A..1300GHz

Plane.energy.sampleSize.tipHTML:
The size of the detector sampling of spectral energy. Typically the spectral resolution is two or more times the spectral sampling. A search value of "2 nm" implies a spectral dispersion of 2nm/pixel. Allowed wavelength, frequency, energy units are as for Spectral Coverage. It is advised to enter a range of values using > or < or two values separated by two dots.

Clickable examples:

  • 0.2..0.4nm
  • < 0.2nm
  • 2..3GHz

Plane.energy.resolvingPower.tipHTML:
The ratio of wavelength or frequency to the spectral resolution in the same units, commonly known as R. It is advised to enter a range of values using > or < or two values separated by two dots.

Clickable examples:

  • > 50000
  • 8000..30000

Plane.energy.bounds.width.tipHTML:
Specify the wavelength coverage of the observation. Only observations that have spectral coverage that matches this range will be returned. For example, to find broad-band imaging one might query for observations with a range that exceeds 200nm while narrow-band imaging would be returned by searching for observations with a bandpass width of less than 100nm. It is advised to enter a range of values using > or < or two values separated by two dots.

Clickable examples:

  • 200..300nm
  • > 0.200nm
  • < 1000A
  • > 80GHz

Plane.energy.restwav.tipHTML:
Search using a single rest-frame energy value or a range of rest-frame energy values (default units are metres). Multiple values in a range should be separated by two dots. This constraint can only be used for cases where the rest-frame frequency or wavelength of the observation has been specified in the database. Note that single values assume a range of +/-0.5% to match the database values. Allowed wavelength, frequency, energy units are: [ Hz, kHz, MHz, GHz, cm, mm, um, nm, m, A, eV, keV, MeV, GeV ]

Clickable examples:

  • 1.2E-3
  • 0.8457mm
  • 354.5054GHz
  • 354.50..354.51GHz

Plane.energy.DOWNLOADCUTOUT.tipHTML: Check this box to return image cutouts rather than full images. Cutouts will be constrained to the range in the "Spectral Coverage" box.

download_data.tipHTML: Direct downloads of the observations selected in the table below and filtered by the product types selected to the left.

download_option_product_type.tipHTML: Filter the download by one or more specific Product Types.

download_option_cutout_checkbox.tipHTML: Check this box to download spatial cutouts centred on the requested position and with a radius as specified on the query page, rather than full images.

DataID.Collection.tipHTML: short name for the data collection

Curation.releaseDate.tipHTML: timestamp of date the data becomes publicly available

Char.TimeAxis.numBins.tipHTML: dimensions (number of pixels) along the time axis

Char.TimeAxis.Coverage.Bounds.Limits.tipHTML: Interval of observation dates, or single date value (MJD)

Char.SpectralAxis.numBins.tipHTML: dimensions (number of pixels) along the energy axis

Char.SpectralAxis.Coverage.Bounds.Limits.tipHTML: Interval of spectral coordinate values, or single value

Char.SpatialAxis.numBins2.tipHTML: dimensions (number of pixels) along the other spatial axis

Char.SpatialAxis.numBins1.tipHTML: dimensions (number of pixels) along one spatial axis

Char.SpatialAxis.Coverage.Bounds.Extent..tipHTML: size of the region covered (~diameter of minimum bounding circle)

Char.PolarizationAxis.stateList.tipHTML: polarization states present in the data

Char.PolarizationAxis.numBins.tipHTML: dimensions (number of pixels) along the polarization axis

Char.ObservableAxis.ucd.tipHTML: UCD describing the observable axis (pixel values)

Char.SpectralAxis.DOWNLOADCUTOUT.tipHTML: Check this box to return image cutouts rather than full images. Cutouts will be constrained to the range in the "em_min" and "em_max" boxes.
